nova/api/metadata/base.py.message: Please comment on this version. 2018-08-27 is already in the future so I'm not sure what version I should use here.

Note to self: so, looks like this is supposed to be the initial release date for rocky [1] which should be 2018-08-30. The last time we had two version changes in one release, the first version was earlier than the final release date for the cycle.

I'm wondering if this format 2018-08-27-2 is valid for consumers of the metadata API? We haven't had a version of that format before.

[1] https://releases.openstack.org/

Yes, I put a bogus version on purpose to trigger a discussion. I don't know which date to put here. I think ROCKY_ONE should have been the date for milestone-1, not the final release. Now we are stuck with it. What now? Any suggestion? =)
This should be a set if it's just to check membership.
OK this is where we hide unreleased stuff, so just lump the changes into the existing ROCKY version and remove the ROCKY_ONE/TWO things.
Is this right for creating the previous version behavior? I thought the previous behavior was that 'services' only contained the services from the first subnet?

I see that now about 'networks' and 'services' both changing from first subnet => all subnets. I agree that they should match. What I didn't realize is that previously, 'networks' only contained the first subnet as well.

So the only two options are 1) if 'ip_addresses' was added only for the first subnet, then nothing else changes. Or 2), if 'ip_addresses' is added per subnet (per 'networks'), then 'services' will contain all subnets too (which is what we have here currently).

Sorry I didn't understand that until I looked through this implementation -- lack of knowledge on my part.

Finally, I noticed the same thing you mention, that 'services' seems redundant since it's already under 'networks'. I guess it's just supposed to be a shortcut rollup of all networks services. I wouldn't remove it.

Yes, the previous behavior was to only contain the services from the first subnet. If "networks" now has info for all subnets, I think it should also have info for all services. Otherwise why don't we remove "services" ? The "networks" also has the same "services" field. Let me know what you think this should be.

nova/virt/netutils.py.message:
Okay, so you're doing this instead of the previous way where subnet_v4 and subnet_v6 would be None if network['subnets'] was empty and several statements were guarded with 'if subnet_v4 or subnet_v6'.

Instead of that, you skip the rest of the logic if no subnet.
Yes, I think there is no reason to deal with v4 and v6 in different ways. The logic is the same.

This is a good idea but I have to admit, the question comes up, "Can we depend on 'version' being set in the subnet dict?"

(later) Based on the _get_first_subnet method (formerly _get_first_network), we can depend on the presence of the 'version' key in the subnet dict.
Yes, I think we can rely on it. Otherwise get_first_subnet would fail much earlier.

releasenotes/notes/multiple-fixed-ips-ne.message: We should probably mention the new metadata API version these are found in.
Done. Will update with proposed version on next change.

And "services" will now contain a union of the services found in all of the subnets, right? And that is different from the previous metadata API version, correct? I do wonder if that could somehow cause a problem for anyone relying on existing behavior.
A list or dict having more values is definitely an additive change. A non-additive change would be changing the name of a key,  the data type of something, etc.
I also don't see any mention of a change in the behavior of the "services" field in the spec for this work.
People relying on existing behavior should ask for the previous version. I will update release note to mention the new behavior. Should I also update the spec?

I had another look at the spec and found the mention of "include all the subnets", which is where the changes to the 'networks' field and 'services' field come from. Maybe it's just me, but it would have helped me to see that more explicitly stated in the spec.

In total, it looks like we have a few changes:

 * addition of 'ip_addresses' subfield under the 'networks' field
 * 'networks' field now contains all subnets, not just first subnet
 * 'services' field now contains all subnets, not just first subnet

My concern comes from being unclear about whether returning more networks/services in the existing 'networks'/'services' field is considered a "change" or an "addition". As you recall, when we started talking about the metadata API change for fixed ips, there was a discussion wherein we learned that we can only add to the API, not "change" it, even though "changes" are allowed under the EC2 API versioning our metadata API is based on. This has been the precedent in the nova metadata API.

So, let me double check with dansmith and mriedem since they know a lot more about the metadata API than I do, and get their ack on the 'networks' and 'services' behavior. I'll ask them tomorrow.

nova/policies/servers.py.message: Why wouldn't this include system so a global admin can list all instances across all projects? Same below for detail.
agree Matt

I think for v1 of this system scope thing rolling out, the defaults need to be the same as what admin means today, which is "god". So god > project admin > project user.

For deployments that do hosted openstack, then the hosting operator is the system scope admin and the project admin at the customer site is the 'project' scope admin, and can only list instances for their project, but the admin at the hosting deployer can list all instances for all projects.

For deployments like that, they could tweak the policy if these defaults aren't going to work for them (likely they are already doing policy workarounds for the lack of system vs project scope admin roles right?).

Then maybe over time we can start to restrict the default scoping rules on the APIs, which would come with upgrade notes and such.

Yeah - this is exactly the question that I think needs to be asked. For context, this is how I'm approaching it.

`system` scope is intended to used for APIs that interact with the deployment on a system level (e.g. listing hypervisors). Where I start to stumble is mixing this with project-owned resources like instances.

I guess it really depends on how the projects in a deployment are set up. If all the projects bubble up to a single parent project, or domain, index:get_all_tenants would be accomplished by listing instances with a token scoped to that ultimate parent project or domain (since it's the root of the tree).

If projects are in a flat structure, then scoping a token to to a parent project such that you can list everything in the deployment because it's a tree structure isn't possible. And maybe that's OK? I'm not sure..

At the same time, you can go about this from the opposite view point. If we switch this to be `system` instead of `project`, it will mean only users with system role assignments can view all instances, which is fine from an administrative perspective. But we're requiring that people scope to a thing that has nothing to do with what the instances are encapsulated in (e.g. to list all instances in all projects, A, B, and C, you need to get a system-scoped token). Which kind of led to the original problem that this is trying to fix.

This will probably be the first of many cases like this. I'm open to any feedback here.
What about this one?
So - host would be a hypervisor right? If so, then yes, this should totally be a `system` scoped operation.

This is creating an instance on a specific host. Should probably be consistent with show:host_status above. It's unclear to me what should and shouldn't be possible for a project admin, but if we assume that by default all admin rules today work for a global admin, then I'm not sure why we wouldn't default to project + system.

If the host information is considered sensitive in the sense that your average user shouldn't know about it, then I'd be inclined to make this a system-level operation.

In the project-admin case, how are they supposed to get system-level hypervisor information if they don't have access to query the system?

In the system-admin case, they are creating an instance to be owned by a project with a token that isn't scoped to that project.

I'm wondering what case is right for usability. Thoughts?
I don't know why this doesn't use base.RULE_ADMIN_API. Is there a difference?

That's a good question. It could be something that is processed by oslo.context? I'd need to dig into this. What I'm working towards should be preventing things like this... My ideal view is specifically found in the examples here: https://trello.com/c/C1INH5AI/7-define-default-roles

This policy is checked down in the neutron API code if you're trying to attach to shared=False external network and you're not an admin, it fails by default:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eabd1c11fdcadc49c0d4185c32b04202ef4dd69d/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py#L481

Regarding the scope, I'm not sure what the use case would be for a 'global' admin to do this to an instance in a project, but I assume that if this meant only admins could do this before, then they could do it to any instance regardless of project, so this is probably the correct scope list so we don't break backward compatibility.
We can always introduce the correct scope list initially and build a service-wide toggle that enforces scope. I mocked this up in keystone here - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528847/
++, well documented.
Isn't it necessary to specify 'system' also here with the above reason? It would be better to write a NOTE about that because of the same 'get_all_tenants' operation.
Done
I think that depends on how to define this scope_types on os-hypervisors API. If defining 'system' only on the API, here also should be 'system' here, they should be consistent.
Done
Needs to be system scoped.  A project scoped token should not be allowed to break out of project scoped resources.  This is a system admin level operation
Done
Why not specify scope_types here?
Done
agreed.  Project scope
Done

The info in "port" dic is the new port info which need to be updated.

2.Make the UUIDs be the same between neutron and Core OVN, this need to wait my patch[3] to merge, I think it needs a long time, and we need do much work on ovsdbapp.

3.If we record UUID of qos policy of neutron in external_ids of QoS in core OVN is not a bad choice,though I think it will be costly when search the target,but we have done many similar features. It need to change ovsdbapp and neutron. I think it is not complicated, and is a suitable way to do.

nova/compute/api.py.message: I'm not familiar with this idiom...why this rather than setting _NO_STATE=set([None]) and skipping the lines at 135/136 ?

It's actually a reasonably common idiom: it's just a shorthand which creates a unique, immutablish sentinel. It's normally used as an argument default which I'm not doing there, but I'm still using it as an argument sentinel (see line 2208).

I'm going to change it anyway, though: it's never returned or passed to anything so there's no risk of it being modified. I'm consequently also going to change its name to be more specific (I think I was originally going to use it for vm_state too, but that doesn't make sense).

I believe to be readable it's worth to describe params,
like:

vm_state: (None, string, list)
  None - state is not checked
  ...
task_state: (None, _NO_STATE, string, list)
  None - state is not checked
  _NO_STATE - state has to be None
  ...

It's really not explicit.
Actually I should probably have updated the whole text to describe the new behaviour. I'll do that.
I'm guessing this is here to allow us to use both a list and a single variable for this attribute
nit: do you need these still?

Yes it is needed. A decorator shall be a function that takes the decorated function as a parameter. By calling check_instance_state() we get back outer from L153 that takes the decorated function as parameter. Instead @check_instance_state would mean that the check_instance_state function will take the decorated function as parameter. Which is not true our case.

and the second.

Do we need tests for these? Is it something that could even be tested?
I agree to add some test to these cases. Also it seems that we have no unit test coverage for the check_instance_state decorator either.

nova/virt/libvirt/imagecache.py.message:
How are you sure unless you're checking the minimum nova-compute service version in the deployment? Like is done here:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/417961/41/nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py@178

In other words, when the newton change referenced in the commit message merged, the service version was 11:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2c389ccc8c266175a71a29358bec7fe219e64fe0/nova/objects/service.py

So for this code to run with a guarantee that code is deployed, it would have to only do this if the minimum nova-compute service version in the deployment was > 11.
I must admit, I also thought the n and n-1 coexistence policy to be the default one and have followed that through on multiple reviews. Are you sure this isn't the case??

It was my understanding that we explicitly don't support deployments with a mixture of N and N-2. At most we support N and N-1, which is the assumption made here. We assume here that because this is Ocata, there may be Newton nodes but not Mitaka nodes. This has come up at a bunch of summits and operators meetups and we've always been unambiguous about it, so I'm pretty surprised if this isn't the case.

I'm trying to delete obsolete code here. I could add in the service check, but that would add code, not delete it. If we can safely make assumptions about how old a compute node we might be co-existing with, I think the solution of just deleting the code is better.

Our upgrade docs in the nova devref only talk about n and n+1 for rolling upgrades, and that's what we test with using grenade. The upgrade and rolling upgrade tags in the governance repo also aren't very clear on not supporting n-2 computes (which isn't a surprise since they aren't nova-specific tags). So I'm not aware of anything specifically saying we don't support n-2, the tags just say that configs from n-1 should work in n, which is what we support for changes and deprecations to config options. But we don't have anything specifically saying we don't support n-2, and we have the service version stuff to tell us, which is why I was bringing it up.

the "ceph" command is only found inside the containers and we can really only set the noout flag from within a MON container

another, probably more general comment is that we need to do the set/unset only once; it is probably acceptable to set/unset it once for every node undergoing migration but we should not be setting/unsetting this in parallel from multiple nodes because it applies to the entire cluster

sounds to me the step2/set > step4/unset idea would work pretty well, especially if we can make it run on bootstrap node on the role hosting MONs only

but are we able to trigger a command in the MON container when other roles, like computes, are running this code?

 - if update a ceph osd (how do I do I know that)
   - delegate to bootstrap node to do something like podman exec -ti ceph-mon ceph osd set noout (omg ...)
   - when done with that osd, unset it

Now that serial could be something !=1 and that role can be updated in //, then I would need a global lock to not unset it at the wrong time ... man this is getting out of hand ... 

other solution :
 - if step2 and bootstrap node, something like podman exec -ti ceph-mon ceph osd set noout
 - update everything
 - if step4 and bootstrap node, podman exec -ti ceph-mon ceph osd unset noout

playbookconfig/centos/playbookconfig.spe.message: Have you tested a remote playbook run? I am asking because it looks like the trident-installer would now have to be installed on the remote host. If so, that would require an update to the README.rst. A question for Tee - is there a distinction between packages required on controller-0 vs. packages required on the remote host? I see the pyparted, sysinv and cgts-client are all in the requires list here, but not listed in the README.rst. How does that work?
Apparently for remote-play, users need to clone the ansible-playbooks git repo, not install the RPM built from the sources. So, for remote-play, these dependencies play no role.

Packages listed in the README.rst are packages required for the execution of Ansible & its modules, not the execution of user's scripts/commands included in the playbook (e.g. shell, command, copy are Ansible modules whereas tridentctl is the user's command).

When a task is executed, Ansible transfers the needed module and user's related files where applicable to the target host and execute the task there. For instance to run the following task:

- name: Add NetApp backend
  command: tridentctl -n {{ trident_namespace }} create backend -f {{ backend_file }}
  args:
    chdir: "{{ trident_setup_dir }}"
  environment:
    KUBECONFIG: "/etc/kubernetes/admin.conf"

Ansible would transfer its "command" module code and execute it on target host which supposedly has the environment to run tridentctl.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
right so there is an architectural issue here too.
placement should be the single source of truth for capacity info. the cyborg data bases should only be used for assignment and state tracking.

so we should be doing the placement update first and only update the cyborg database after that completes successfully so that the cyborg db never gets out of sync with placement.

the other architecual issue is the placmeent update should be done entirly form the cyborg compute agent and not via the conductor but thats a separate issue to be addressed at a later data.

the current implementation will not scale  as it centralises the compute and update in the conductor process and will have issue when deploy in a distributed/edge toplogy. effectively the agent will ddos the conductor when deployed in large numbers. ideally each agent would local compute the new state then update placement directly and only after its internal state and placement have been updated, it would finally update the cyborg database via the conductor.
Hi. Pls see the below reply.

Many thanks for your valued suggestions, Sean!
Modifying the current architecture of the resource report is one of the cyborg's important tasks. 
"Compute agent collect its internal state and report directly to placement", "after these are done, update cyborg DB". These are very good ideas. We'll discuss with other cyborg contributors in our weekly meeting.
Thanks again!

the issue seam totally valid by the way i just not sure if the patch will really help improve the situation.

if we think we should fail fast then you can ignore my try/excpet/finally suggestion.
ok if the agent recovers when placement is operational again then i guess that is fine. what i was worreid about is the service stopping and not restarting.
Yes, I have tested it in the devstack env. It will automatically return to normal when the placement-api service returns to normal.

Thanks sean for your quick review!
In my opinion, according to the current architecture where cyborg and placement have two independent databases, when the placement fails, cyborg's own database should stop updating and throw exceptions quickly.

I manually stopped and started the placement-api service, and did several experiments in the devstack environment. The results show that this solution works well. It can quickly cause the cond and agent services to throw exceptions, but instead of directly bringing the service down, it is still active. When you use systemctl status to view the cond and agent services.
However, the log will show that the placement-api exception caused the data diff to fail. When the placement-api service returns to normal, there are no errors in the log, and the data can continue to diff.
The architecture of accelerator resource synchronization and whether placement should be updated in the cond process will be discussed in the next period. I think this patch is a good idea at present, wait to see the opinions of other friends

Will update it, thanks.

where is this exception eventurally caught?
we dont want this to propagate all the way to the main function and kill the agent or conductor in this case.

The current idea is to expose the exception directly to the cond and agent services. This will not cause the service to hang directly, but this exception can be found through the log file. When the placement service returns to normal in the next cycle, cond and agent will return to normal.

cyborg/conductor/manager.py.message:
reordering does not really help.
if the delete triggers a 503 responce then the added will not be processed. similarly for added and same.

i would suggest factorign out each loop into a separate inner function then cain this using a try,except,finally


def drv_device_make_diff (...):
  ...

  error = None

  def remove_deleted (...):
   for d in deleted:
            old_driver_dev_obj = old_driver_device_list[old_cpid_list.index(d)]
            for driver_dep_obj in old_driver_dev_obj.deployable_list:
                rp_uuid = self.get_rp_uuid_from_obj(driver_dep_obj)
                self._delete_provider_and_sub_providers(context, rp_uuid)
            old_driver_dev_obj.destroy(context, host)

  def create_added(...):
    ...

  def update_same(...):
    ...


  stub_cpid_list = [driver_dev_obj.controlpath_id.cpid_info for
                          driver_dev_obj in new_driver_device_list
                          if driver_dev_obj.stub]
        new_cpid_list = [driver_dev_obj.controlpath_id.cpid_info for
                         driver_dev_obj in new_driver_device_list]
        old_cpid_list = [driver_dev_obj.controlpath_id.cpid_info for
                         driver_dev_obj in old_driver_device_list]
        same = set(new_cpid_list) & set(old_cpid_list) - set(stub_cpid_list)
        added = set(new_cpid_list) - same - set(stub_cpid_list)
        deleted = set(old_cpid_list) - same - set(stub_cpid_list)
        host_rp = self._get_root_provider(context, host)

try:
   remove_deleted(...)
except ServiceUnaviailable as ex:
  error = ex
finally:
  try:
    create_added(...)

   remove_deleted(...)
  except ServiceUnaviailable as ex:
      error = ex
  finally:
    try:
      update_same(...)
    except ServiceUnaviailable as ex:
      error = ex
    finally:
       if error:
         raise error


this should allow the function to try and continue to make progress if the outage is only temporay and we will still raise the exception at the end if there is one. it might be over kill but there isnt really any value in just reordering the function as it not any more correct then the current order.
Yes, after you emphasized that the function of this code is reorder, I believe this is helpful for others to review this code. Thanks again.

well over all i think this patch imporves the situation even if it does not fully address all corner cases and the reordering is not harmful so im ok with this i just wanted to highlight the delete works and add fails case so that people were generally aware of that when reviewing.

addressing the architectural question i agree should be handled seperately so im going to change my review to a +1

Hi sean. Adjusting the order of the delete and add methods is helpful. Because the delete method first calls the placement interface, when the placement service is unavailable, the update to cyborg db will stop at this time, so that no intermediate dirty data will be generated. But this does not completely solve all data synchronization problems, because there may be such a situation:
When the delete method is updated, but the placement service is unavailable when the add method is used, no matter what to do, dirty data will be generated in the middle.
With regard to fully addressing this issue, further discussion of the design of the architecture may be required. Please see my reply in the commit message, thank you.
About delete and added check, do you thinking about abstracting out a private method? And explain the abstract method. Reduce code redundancy.

Yes, I thought about this too. We might find the current code a bit redundant, but readability is good. Personally, I think that abstracting it alone will not save a lot of code, but will make the logic of the code more difficult to understand. If you have a good idea or conclusion, you can submit a patch and we can review it together.

Don't we? On https://github.com/redhat-service-assurance/telemetry-framework/pull/100 I was proposing to make this part of the default set.

Also on that PR I'm asking for input from both you and Ryan about what should merge upstream (here) and it looks like Ryan is already doing that work, so we're converging on exactly the same day!
Also remove this as a default plugin.

I see you're stealing my configuration from upstream :) Be default we do not want to enable these ExtraConfig options. As noted, check with Chris Sibbitt about what the default configuration should look like here.
I thought we did want to enable them.

Leif was advocating[1] for using `CollectdDefaultPlugins` here to get specifically the set of plugins SAF is tested and supported with and no more. 

"we want to override the generic defaults for collectd because in our case, we want to clearly define exactly what we're enabling and how. [the concern] is that someone changes the default plugins on us (which we would otherwise rely on) and enables a plugin that overwhelms the SmartGateway. In that case we'd get an escalation on cloud update if that were to happen."

I agree with his reasoning; especially because right now the defaults include the "tcpconns" plugin[2], which is very noisy and we'd strongly prefer to have disabled when SAF is being used (at least by default). There is a counter-argument though, where a future addition to the default plugins required for new openstack functionality would be broken if this SAF config is installed in a way that overrides it. So I think in reality we might see problems either way. My own opinion on the recommended course of action from here is to propose that "tcpconns" actually be removed from the defaults[2], then continue to use `CollectdExtraPlugins` here because I think that more naturally fits the intended model, even if it puts us at risk of getting new metrics during a cloud update.

[1] https://github.com/redhat-service-assurance/telemetry-framework/pull/100/files#r350241489
[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/metrics/collectd-container-puppet.yaml#L90
Re-defining CollectdDefaultPlugins is pretty dangerous/nasty. At least in the past, you could remove the unixsock plugin from being installed. CollectdExtraPlugins is the safer option here.

As said before:
- When using CollectdDefaultPlugins: when you use that in your own .yaml files, all previously defined plugins will get replaced. Health checks rely on unixsock being loaded. If you don't include unixsock in CollectdDefaultPlugins, health checks will fail. That is hard to debug.

What I'm saying here is: Please use CollectdExtraPlugins for modifications or where ever possible; that is going to be merged with CollectdDefaultPlugins.

I keep pointing at ExtraPlugins as we should not hint that CollectdDefaultPlugins can/should be modified.

The unixsock plugin is/was getting added to CollectdDefaultPlugins hidden somewhere in tht, but it will be overridden in a .yaml file one may/would probably have.

In the longer path, we should just fix CollectdDefault and ExtraPlugins, have only one list and make that extensible.


I am happy to shut up and will direct all escalations/bugs with collectd health checks in your direction?

I don't understand your comment. You said we should use ExtraPlugins here (which would not override the list of Default plugins as far as I understand it, but rather would get merged with the Defaults list).

So are you suggesting this is the correct approach, or not the correct approach?

No we don't need to change defaults overall. Why do you think that is required?

As said, this here is hinting it is a good idea to change CollectdDefaultPlugins per deployment.

What I'm saying is that we want to explicitly set the default set of plugins and not have to rely on looking at some other location to determine what the default list of plugins is, and then build our own manual mapping of ExtraPlugins and then determine what the actual full mapping of the plugins is.

If we don't define the full list of plugins here and only use the ExtraPlugins, then we are at the mercy of whatever the current set of DefaultPlugins is, and we're going to end up having the inverse problem of having to dig and determine what changed between THT releases where the DefaultPlugins was modified under us.

If the only issue is that unixsock is always made available, then a patch should be created that results in that rather than having to work around building a single mapping from two separate locations that are bound to change at some point. Or change CollectdDefaultPlugins to only contain `unixsock` as the only plugin, and then rely on CollectdExtraPlugins to define the entire expected list of plugins that we want.

I'm not sure the final snarky comment was necessary.

Then we need to change the defaults overall. Thought we had this discussion already though?

Yea we did:  https://github.com/redhat-service-assurance/telemetry-framework/pull/100#discussion_r349455002

This doesn't quite match exactly what is in our current recommended default setup here:

https://github.com/redhat-service-assurance/telemetry-framework/blob/941cb269ada6e6d622383e3b603e25396fe3307d/tests/infrared/metrics-collectd-qdr.yaml.template

For example, the `connectivity` plugin is an events plugin, and I'm not sure we want to enable those by default currently. We want to focus on metrics at this point I believe.

I've gone through the list and basically the only difference is that you have `connectivity` here. If you just remove it, then it'll match exactly what was in telemetry-framework/100.
We really don't want to modify default plugins unless we are removing any. Please use CollectdExtraPlugins for adding extra plugins.

Thanks for weighing in on this, Martin.

I'd like to remind all reviewers that we ARE removing a plugin, "tcpconns", and that if we use CollectdExtraPlugins (which I support), we will need to merge a patch to the defaults that removes tcpconns from the list.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can you cite this policy? If OpenStack has a policy against publishing binary artifacts, we should not do this. Maybe then it would better happen under the OpenDev tent?

The policy is here:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20170530-binary-artifacts.html#guidelines

The main crux is that we should not provide artifacts that make it seem like they are "official output" of the openstack project - which is why this is being published to osclient/ and not openstack/ ... this is a very common pattern - magnum, kolla and loci off the top of my head all publish images to non-openstack namespaces because they need to publish images somewhere but as a whole we don't want to centrally publish those to an openstack/ branded location and imply some sort of project warranty.

Pete raises a valid point - this is why service-specific dashboards will likely be difficult, as it would require knowledge of the host name to use here and we can't guarantee the defaults will be used. To successfully achieve this here, we either need to keep these service-specific dashboards as drill downs or find a way to utilize template variables in Grafana to select these host names via labels we can guarantee exist
